moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4: I start with the queen's gambit.
moves.2... dxc4 3. e3 Bf5 4. Bxc4 e6 5. Nc3 Bb: White has a slight lead in development, but his DSB is bad.
moves.8. Nf3 Bg4 9. h3 Bxf3: ?! I'm not sure if this is a good move. It trades a bishop for a knight, loses his only active piece and allows my queen to develop.
moves.10. Qxf3 c6: White has an edge here. I'm fully developed, have the bishop pair, (although my DSB is still miserable) and I am much more active than black.
moves.11. O-O b5: He pushes back my bishop, but he should finish developing.
moves.12. Bb3 O-O 13. a3: Gives my LSB an escape hole in case he pushes his a pawn.
moves.13... Nf5: ! Gets his knight more active. He still needs to develop his other knight though.
moves.14. Rfe1 Nh4: ?! It does chase my queen, but he *really* needs to finish developing. This also brings his only active piece onto the edge.
moves.15. Qg3: ? Better would have been g4. This lets him chase my queen again and move back to his earlier spot.
moves.15... g5: ? And he doesn't. He seems to want to preserve his knight's position on the rim even if it costs him his king safety. I don't see why he doesn't just play Nf5. He would have made his knight more active and chased my queen.
moves.16... Nf5: *Now* he moves back, after he's compromised his king safety.
moves.18... Kg7 19. Qxf5: Now black is in BIG trouble. He's down four points and my bishop and queen are hovering over his king.
moves.19... Qd6 20. d5: Defends my LSB and clears the way for my DSB to join the attack.
moves.20... c5 21. b4: Preventing him from chasing my DSB.
moves.21... cxb4: ?? Loses a rook to a skewer.
moves.22. axb4: ???? I don't spot it until right after I make my move.
moves.23... Qb6 24. Bd4 Qd6: ?? And he gives me another chance. This time, I take it.
moves.25. Bc5 Qd8 26. Bxf8+ Qxf8: ?? Blunder, now he'll lose his queen and soon will be checkmated.
moves.27... Kh6: Allows instant mate. He could have drawn it out by blocking with his queen.
